awd_titl_txt: Mechanisms of Color Vision: Genomics, Physiology and Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
More than a million animals on the planet are presumed to use color vision to find food, to find mates and to avoid being eaten by predators. This is because color information is more reliable than other kinds of visual cues like an object's brightness.  Despite the widespread use of color by animals to advertise to potential mates and to warn predators against attack, scientists know very little about the way color vision works in most organisms, including why color vision differs between males and females in some species.  This project aims to examine vision in a group of toxic butterflies that display a new form of coloration on their wings, ultraviolet-yellow, and have novel violet and ultraviolet photoreceptors in their eyes. This project will identify key parts of their genome which control eye development and the placement of photoreceptors in their eyes, which differ between the sexes.   The differences in ability between males and females to detect color will be studied using behavioral tests and linked to cues in the butterflies' light environment which contribute to their survival and reproduction. In addition, this project will result in the training of the next generation of scholars - graduate and postdoctoral students in physiological methods, which will permit the recording of an animal's response to light. Undergraduates will be trained in the annotation of genomes. Lastly, the project will make freely-available a method for increasing the production of difficult-to-study light-sensitive proteins, which may be useful for a variety of biotechnology applications. 

Mimetic animal coloration evolves in the context of predator confusion. Unless mimetic animals have adaptations for discriminating between mimetic colors there is a risk of confusion for the animals themselves, with negative consequences for mating and reproduction. Heliconius butterflies are of interest because many unpalatable species have formed mimicry rings in the Neotropics. The research team has discovered that Heliconius eyes express duplicated ultraviolet (UV) opsins and have shown that this duplication may be an adaptation for species recognition, via enhanced UV color vision. The proposed project will permit the elucidation of the biological significance of the ultraviolet opsin duplication by tracing species- and sex-specific patterns of photoreceptor evolution using immunohistochemistry, character mapping, and ancestral state reconstruction. In addition the project will draw on a Heliconius butterfly reference genome together with other genomic resources and transcriptomic resources that the project will generate, to identify eye genes that may have been the target of selection in these different lineages along with the duplicate UV opsin gene. The proposed work will reveal in unprecedented detail the evolution of color vision within a group of closely-related butterflies in relation to the signals they encounter in their daily lives. Whereas there has been much work on sexual dimorphism in signals, there is virtually no work on sexual dimorphism in sensory systems especially in color vision. This is a major gap that we can now begin to fill using a variety of methods: Pac-Bio and Illumina DNA-sequencing, ATAC-seq, RNA-seq, intracellular electrophysiology, cell culture, and behavioral tests.

por.por_cntn:
Introduction

The funding provided for this research project supported a comprehensive exploration of vision, evolutionary biology, comparative physiology, and genetics. Centered on butterflies in the genus Heliconius, the research investigated mechanisms that these animals employ in color perception and color signaling. Collaboration expanded the project's scope to other organisms, offering insights into the universal principles of color and color perception in animals.

Physiological Systems and Behavioral Insights

Central to our findings is the visual system of butterflies, which underlies their perception of a wide spectrum of colors, including ultraviolet. Such visual capability is central to behaviors such as foraging, mate selection, and employing aposematic signals to deter predators. The study also addressed the role of coloration in butterfly wings, which is achieved through both pigments and nanostructures. We document the role of such coloration in thermal regulation and signaling, highlighting the critical role of visual and pigmentation systems in ecological interactions.

Evolutionary Adaptations

In our previous research, we established the importance of ultraviolet (UV) opsin gene evolution in Heliconius vision. Our research here further elaborates the evolutionary pressures that contribute to tuning of UV opsin genes--critical for color vision--thus leading to a spectrum of color perception abilities across species. This diversity cuts across color perception, the physiological arrangement of eye structures, and distribution of photoreceptors between sexes. This physiological diversity in vision has occurred alongside structural wing adaptations balancing visibility and camouflage with thermal management.

Gene expression studies in eye and brain tissues reveal how insects regulate important genes in response to varying environments. A noteworthy finding is related to phototransduction genes, where differences between diurnal butterflies and nocturnal moths showcase how these animals evolve to survive in such diverse ecological niches.

Sexual Dimorphism and UV Color Vision

One pivotal discovery revealed the genetic basis for sexual dimorphism in UV color vision among butterfly species in the Heliconius genus. This sexual difference results from the unique positioning of an opsin gene (i.e., UVRh1) in the genome. This gene is present on the W chromosome, which leads to a scenario in which females, but not males, exhibit UV color vision. This novel finding provokes a reevaluation of existing models explaining sexual dimorphism and represents a significant advance in understanding sex differences in sensory perception and the role of new gene traffic in novel expression patterns.

Methodological Rigor and Diversity

Our program's success derives from its methodological diversity. We incorporated genomics, reverse genetics, molecular biology, optical physics, electrophysiology, microscopy, and computational modeling into our research. Techniques such as long-range PCR and sequencing, CRISPR genome editing, and long-read genome assembly were key in interrogating the genetics of our study systems. Phylogenetic models and statistical analyses facilitated the reconstruction of evolutionary histories and the prediction of the functional consequences of specific gene mutations.

Broadening Horizons

Though Heliconius butterflies were our primary focus, the research extended to other animals, including humans, highlighting the shared genetic and physiological mechanisms of vision across species. Such cross-species integration advances our understanding of the intricate machinery behind color vision, highlighting features shared between only distantly related species.

Broader Impacts

Our project has contributed to improving public knowledge of the color vision of butterflies via articles featuring our research published in the New York Times, Popular Science, New Scientist, Le Monde, and F1000 Prime, among other venues. In addition, Dr. Briscoe was interviewed by NPR, RadioBio and Big Biology podcasts, filmed for a PBS documentary, featured in Professional Women's magazine. She also provided expert commentary for the Atlantic, the New York Times, and other media outlets and delivered a Story Collider science communication performance to the public at the Lyric Hyperion Theater in Los Angeles. The project also contributed to the development of the U.S. STEM workforce by supporting the training of three postdoctoral fellows, eight graduate students, and seven undergraduates. 

Conclusion

The research program funded by this grant reveals the complex interrelations between genetics, physiology, and behavior governing color perception and adaptation. It significantly advances our understanding of fundamental principles of life related to color and perception of color, illustrating the power of our interdisciplinary approach. By tackling these questions with diverse experimental and theoretical tools across diverse physiological systems and organisms, we provided vital insights into the evolutionary dynamics that shape our colorful world.
